UPDATED: JAN 3, 2014 12oz bottle, best before 3/4/05, drunk 12/31/13.Well, 8 years later, here we are...As will become repetitive in some of my forthcoming ratings, why the hell did I age this beer this long (at all??)? Oh well, certainly wont fault the beer for any overly oxidative notes in this review.Pours a very frothy, thick, white foam atop a deep, brassy-golden colored body. About an inch of sludge on the bottom of the bottle from its, ahem, extended lagering stage. Very encouraging appearance.Aroma is enticing, with lemon zest, vanilla soaked, honey-like maltiness and a nice tartness on the end. Oxidation is shockingly minimal. Fingers crossed for the flavor, then.A zap of sourness greets the palate initially, which then gives way to...not much. Haha, seems the yeast has been hungry over the years, eating away any semblance of sugar. The palate is soft and pillowy, with a light, but firm carbonation. Some light straw-like maltiness and a touch of grassiness are all thats left of the beer, other than the (quite delicious) tart acids that have overdeveloped. Still, no flaws and very little oxidation. Clean, no fusels or ethanol detected, extremely low on esters/phenols. Really just some straw and grassiness and the tartness. This must have been dynamite when fresh. Probably shouldnt rate this, but I have a fresh bottle, so I will revisit soon.

22 ounce bottle into signature globe glass; no bottle dating, but it was from the 2012 release.  Pours lightly hazy golden amber color with a nice 2 finger fluffy of white head with incredible retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Nice dense foamy lacing clings to the glass, with a nice amount of streaming carbonation.  Aromas of big lemon, orange zest, pineapple, coriander, pepper, floral, grass, straw, earth, and herbal.  Fantastic aromas with nice complexity and balance; there is a lot of brett presence.  Taste of lemon, orange zest, pineapple, coriander, bread, toast, floral, grass, straw, earth, pepper, and herbal.  Light earthy tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus, pineapple, coriander, bread, toast, floral, straw, grass, earth, and herbal on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice balance and complexity of flavors; nice brett flavor complexity; zero cloying flavors on the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a lightly creamy, crisp, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is highly excellent Biere De Garde!  Great balance and complexity of flavors, with nice brett complexity; very smooth and easy to drink.  I enjoyed this one a lot; one of the better Biere De Gardes I have had.

Bottle. Amber with big foamy dissipating head and some lacing. Smells like cotton candy, lemon, a hint of tobacco, a hint of gum, and almost a minty quality. A clean bitterness with an astringency and light sweetness. Light, clean, pretty carbonated, light bitter and astringent finish. Not bad.
From the bottle poured a hazy golden brew with a thick white head.Aromas of malt, citrus fruit and apple cider. Flavors of lemon, and honey, with a hint of something stink footy. Over all, not bad.

Bottle pours dark gold with an off white head with huge bubbles. Aromas of clove, cinnamon, and funky yeast. Taste is funky yeast, cloves, and some fruit. body is light and finish is sweet and short. Overall a pretty good for NB.
Pours a golden orange with a nice white head, berry nose.. Decent carbonation with some strawberry and Brett flavor...dry finish.  Decent Beer...

UPDATED: APR 26, 2012 Tap pours cloudy yellow orange with tall white head. The aromas are smooth sweet and a little citrusy. The taste is robust and sparkling with lemon and orange citrus, a very smooth blend of grains and a hay like strong hop after bite. All in all it is a little outside the style but a well thought out brew and it is done well. Finishes mostly clean with a strong hop dryness, ends a little brut champagne like. Nice

Pours a clear deep gold with lingering white head.  Strawberry, brett, yeastiness, biscuit in the nose.  Taste is crisp with plenty of berry sourness and some earthiness.  Medium mouthfeel, finishes dry.
Bottle from Ale Yeah! in Decatur, GA. Lightly spiced and spring-y. Tea notes. Good, bright orange color.

translucent copper with a persistant beige head. 

aroma: sour, brett funk, metallic, citrus rind, fruity flanders ale esters, and some biscuity malt.

taste: mostly the brett funk of the aroma, but with some bathroom phenolics rather than the nice flanders sour notes.

Pours a cloudy orange with a foam white head that dissipated quickly. Smells a little grassy with a little bit of funk. Taste is earthy and the Brett is apparent. My first of this style and it was quite refreshing on a hot spring day
This one fell flat for me. Golden-orange pour leads mild doughy aroma. Taste is kind of bland maltiness and oats, citrus is mild-orange to me, the Brett didnt mesh as nicely as Id have hoped.

22oz bottle.
Dull golden pour with some white head.  Aromas of spices, citrus, and earth - flavor is similar with Brett and floral hops.

On tap at Apex, pours a hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of doughy malt - not much on the nose really. Flavour of dry bread, wheat and maybe some yeast - similarly bland flavour profile. Pointless beer to me, yet dry and refreshing. Decent enough I suppose.

Draft. Nice pie spice, caramel, and funk on the aroma. Hazy bronze color and a slightly hazy appearance. I loved the flavor balance between the funky, barnyard notes and the spices, all held together by a nice, rich sweetness. It wasnt as fizzy or highly carbonated as most Biere de Gardes, not that thats a negative, just different.

Courtesy of my roommate Ryan. Pours a cloudy goldenrod color. Smells like funky, yeasty citrus. Delicate carbonation. Tastes tart and slightly sour, like a funky Belgian hefeweizen. Nice wheat, citrus, and mild peppery spice flavors. Tastes slightly mild, but is probably just right for a hot day.
Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours cloudy orange with orange and clove aroma, tastes like white orange peel. Rather flat, light body. Not amazing.

Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. Hazy orange with a white head. Yeasty and fruity aroma with citrus and light funky notes. Spicy yeasty flavor with some fruitiness, some sweetness and a dry finish. Medium-bodied.

A - Pours a fairly clear amber-orange color with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down slowly leaving behind some thick lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of funkiness and sourness with some Belgian yeast, lemon zest, spice, touch of grain.

T - Starts off with some tartness and funkiness with some Brett, Belgian yeast, and a bit of light spice. Through the middle, some lemon zest, wheat, and a touch of bready malt. The finish is a mix of tartness and sourness with some lemon zest, spice, and funky Brett.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, sour, and funky finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nicely balanced with a good balance of tart and sour flavors.
Aroma is candied and spicy-candy apple and nutmeg. Medium bodied, more candy apple on the palate with baking spices on the back palate. Very tasty

UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 At the 3rd israeli sour tasting, thanks beerandbeyond, pours orange-yellow honey with a medium head, aroma of hops, brett, bread crust, flavor of dust, orange light bitterness, spices, medium bodied

Pint at Bearden Beer Market. Clear amber pour with a medium off-white head. Caramel malt nose with mild tartness and Belgian esters. Malty and caramelly flavor with milt tartness before an estery banana finish.

Dark golden color.  Opaque.  Nice white foamy head with plenty of lacing.  Aroma is clove and cinnamon-like with some citrus notes.  Reminds me of Christmas aromas.  There is a mild sweetness in the taste and a dry bitter finish with some astringency.  Not sure if I nailed the aroma, but its very nice.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2016 Interesting stuff, some herbal spices and the sugary-sweetness that a lot of biere de gardes have. The sourness is subtle and works well. Serving: Bottle

Pours cloudy orange-gold, as advertised, with a thick, creamy off white cap. Nose is some dust, herbal notes and tea leaves, light citrus, perfume. Taste is some sweet, some bitter, and just slightly more tartness. Palate is kind of flat, very light, with some prickliness and almost a little warmth for the low-ish ABV, and a long-lasting tart finish. This beer is all about subtle nuance, and I like that. Its very balanced, and somewhat of a challenge to wrap all of my senses around. Its not ostentatious in any way. Just very nice all around.

Tap at CK. Clear deeper orange with a thicker yellowish head. Webby, weak lace. Nose is sugary and sticky malty with sweetened cherries. Taste is sticky, applely, blander with mealy apple and mineral water tinged with mild butter and powdery sweet rolls. Overly sweet and bland overall. Not good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I love this series.  Very well done.  And this beer is no exception, a tasty treat!
The lemon verbina was a minor component of the taste.  The souring bretenomyces was refreshing with out being overpowering.  I would drink it again
22. Pours a murky medium amber with a creamy white head. Mild caramel nose. Creamy medium body with mild carb. Soft sweet finish. Unremarkable.

Bottle from Whole Foods Vienna.  Hazy orange pour with a fluffy white head.  Biscuity aroma with notes of chocolate.  A bit of funk.  Flavor is very dry and bready.  Notes of lemon.  Bitter finishi.  Pretty smooth and easy to drink.

Bottle. Pours an opaque orange with medium off-white head. Aroma is sweet. Flavor Is dominated by spices that are hard for me to identify. Ive never had anything like this before, but it sure is good!

Aroma- Some citrousy, spiciness, but not a whole lot of aroma.
Appearance- Beautiful hazy orange, tiny white bubble head.
Taste- Definitely citrous up front. Some spiciness in the middle and finishes pretty dry. 
Overall- Drinks really well. Flavors could have been a little bolder, but overall, a good pick up.
Draught at Piece Brewpub, Chicago. Clear yellow/golden - white head. Light malty. Grainy notes. Sweetness. Candlewax. Fruity. Herbal. Light yeasty. Phenolic.

(bottle) Hazy orange body with a small, diminishing off-white head. Interesting aroma that I cant quite put my finger on: some kind of spice, lemon, tropical fruit, a little yeast; moderately malty. Body is thin to medium, but silky, soft carbonation. Flavor of spice, lemon, yeast. Sweet, and low bitterness, but dries out in he finish. Acidic.

I bought a bottle of this and my housemates lady friend drank it, so i bought another one and kinda wish i didnt. The beer had a little too much orange taste to it with some underlying funkiness that didnt really work for me. Not terrible but i guess it wasnt what i was looking for.

Bomber. Aroma consists of creamed corn, doughy bread, grain, nuts, a bit of barnyard funk, wet river rock and lemon rind. Pours hazy orange under a nice lacy off-white head with good retention. Taste is lightly sweet and meaty with little bitterness. Flavor is dusty and nutty. Body is pretty thin, carbonation is average. Crisp and refreshing.

Bottle. Slightly hazy amber with a tall, foamy white head. Aroma is spicy but odd, not unlike a scented candle. Its spicy but sweet and flowery. Taste is also sweet with soft spices, flowers, soft herbal notes and fruit. Body is medium, with a soft, foamy carbonation. Finishes with more fruit, spices, candy notes, sweet malt, flowers and faint herbal notes.

Tap @ Falling Rock, Denver. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, strong notes of caramel, butter, light spicy. Taste is malty, nuts, wood, caramel, light spicyness. Thin to medium body, soft carbonation. 030312

Location: 22 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 3/5/12


Aroma: The nose has a mix of some spiciness, sweet malts, yeast, and fruity notes

Appearance: It pours a clear orange color with a medium off-white head and medium lacing

Flavor: Tastes medium sweet, heavier on the fruity sweet malts, with light notes of spice hop and funk

Palate: Its light-medium bodied, the carbonation is soft-to-average, and the drink is unusual, but refreshing

Overall Impression: 
I thought this was a pretty interesting offering.  The sweetness is most prominent, but there are clear notes of hop and funk here too.  While it isnt a crazy beer, there is something about it that I found a bit unusual, and that is the feel on the mouth.  It was hard to place.  The only comparison that made sense in my head was orange soda, but that wasnt quite on point.  Regardless, I found this beer to pretty drinkable and refreshing, despite being somewhat unable to properly describe it.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a white head. Aroma is very mild, with notes of spice, lemon and sweet malt. Flavor is also super mild, with lemon subtle spice like black pepper and some sweet malt. The body is light with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty disappointing brew.

22 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market in Elizabeth City, NC.  Pours a hazy yellowish-orange with a frothy nearly white head.  Aroma of light funk and orange peel with just a touch of lemon zest.  The flavor is lightly sweet with touches of lemon and orange and just a hint of banana.  Nothing really stands out but the combination works quite nicely.  I prefer my biere de garges to have just a bit more sourness but this is still a really good beer.

Pours hazy amberish gold with a small 1 finger head and good retention.  Aroma is freshly baked bread with a tinge of funk and some herbal character.  Taste is brettanomyces, biscuits, lemon, sage, coriander, caramel.  Body is light and frothy with tiny bubles, medium carbonation, dry mildly bretty finish.  Overall, a really well done brew from New Belgium.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 orange with an amber, though the longer it sits the less amber hue it seems to have. Nice creamy head at the start ends up settling in clusters around the edges. Mild funk in the aroma, sweet oranges. The welcomes you as you take you sip and then comes the sweet. Caramel malt with some banana, some pear, something citric. Medium bodied, kinda creamy, but crisp. Dry finish. A very nice beer and at $5.99 a great deal.
Clear amber pour with a small white head. Caramel toffee and bready nectar and seemingly oxidized malts. Hints of spicy hops, but very bready and doughy. Medium to thick palate with a thick finish.
Pours semi-cloudy orange with a great foamy head. Aroma of bread, spice, banana. Very refreshing flavor with a crisp spicy flavor with a touch of lemon. Nice little beer.

Pours hazy golden with nice lacing.  Banana nut bread on the nose.  Lots of yeasty flavors and citrus, a bit nutty too.  Very enjoyable beer, never tried this style at least that i know.  Pretty complex stuff here, great beer for the spring.
Citrus/fruit, malts and a hint of spice in aroma.  The flavor is heavy on the citrus/orange with an undercurrent of spices and malts that dominates the finish.  Pretty good ale.

Very nice- but this needs to warm up to show everything it offers. Cloudy unfiltered copper with a thin disappaiting head. The nose offers Brett with other light spices. Medium bodies with a gorgeous bubbly mouthfeel. Cardamom on the finish.

Bomber.  A fluffy off white head is three fingers and slow to fade.  Very hazy golden brown with very active bubbles floating up.  This is nicely easy to drink.  Tastes of pepper spice, oatmeal, malts, cereal, barnyard, and yeast.   It is smooth in the mouth.  Some fruit and mild bitterness in the after taste.  This a nice intro to my weekend.  A little something for everyone here.  Nice flavor and a nice beer for those not heavily into craft.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/2/2009.  On tap, served in a pint glass.

Appearance: A golden amber color, maybe even copper. Somewhat hazy, and there was not much head left by the time it arrived at the table. I was pleasantly surprised when the head stuck around and left some nice lacing down the side of the glass.

A light and refreshing aroma of herbs and bready malt, with some light hints of citrus fruit and bananas. The smell is a little bit light, however.

I thoroughly enjoyed the taste of each sip of this beer. The flavor starts with some light herb and yeasty malt. There are distinct flavors of banana and mango, although no more fruit from what I can tell. The hops chime in fairly quickly, bringing some citrus acidity and light bitterness. I am left with the thought of bananas in my head, and there is not much of an aftertaste.

Although it has a lighter body than I would expect from looking at it, it still has a somewhat grainy feel. One complaint I have is that I wish it was a little fuller. 

A nice beer to drink while wondering when the weather is finally going to turn for the better. The flavor is nice, but the light body may wear out its welcome after a few beers. I will most likely revisit this one before Spring is over.

Pours a golden, almost apricot-like color with a thin, fizzy white head that leaves some tracing behind. Light in color but semi-opaque and rich. First thing that hits is rich, malty yeast, which gives way to the spices and then the syrupy citrus finish. My first in the Biere De Gard category and I can see myself giving it another shot, based on this one. This brew is the bombay. Super fancy yet still extremely drinkable. Well done, New Belgium.

Whole Foods, P st, DC 650ml ($8): Pours a reddish colour with a white head. Aroma is mostly fruity with a bit of yeast. I found this beer somewhat disappointing, and more and more am I realizing that I am not a big fan of this style as a whole. I just didnt see too much going on in this beer. It was perfectly drinkable, but it was merely sweet and fruity with some minor yeast funk. I like more funk and perhaps if I were to age this, the funk would manifest itself. Alas in the version I got, nothing exciting was there.

Bottle. Dark gold pour, impressive white head, good retention/some lace. Aroma of lemon, apple, bread, dust. Taste is sweet, husky grain, lemon, fruity esters, light dust. Palate has soft carbonation, grainy finish. Not getting much brett.

Pours ambient orange cloudy, nice white head , good lacing. Malty sour aroma with mild citrus and tropical fruit aroma. Flavor is malt sweet up front gives way to a clean dry finish and a bit of a lemon flavor.  Nice clean drinkable beer.
Bottle. Hazy dark sunflower with a mostly white head. Green apple, some tartness, slight funk. Flavor is green apple and pear with slight bitterness. Lighter body and effervescent carbonation.

Aroma:Light Aroma, some lemon

Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head. Aroma is dirt, metal, and orange. The aroma is not appealing and kinds gross to be honest. The taste is fortunatley much better. Orange peel, lemon, spices. Very light and refreshing. Super dry. Good stuff.
Bottle. Mostly clear orange pour with a big fluffy white head. Aroma is sour cherry. Taste is sour, bready, and complex. Nice!

Draft at Churchkey. Very cloudy copper pour with good, tight head. Nose holds nice bready, spicy malt with cinnamon, toast, and nougat. The flavor brings more of that beautiful sweet caramel and spicy malt, but it is absolutely BONE dry, with just a subtle touch of funk. Light body with low carbonation. Really nice.

Bottle: The aroma has light bready/cereal notes and faint lemon notes. It pours a hazy amber with a small white head that leaves behind minimal lacing. Overall, the lack of aroma hurts my score.
Bottle. Bright golden yellow, huge fluffy white head. Aroma of dusty lemons. Taste is straw, hay, lemon rind. Decent.

22oz bottle. Hazy orange with white head. Smells very yeasty with definite Brett in it. Very very lemony, not a ton of Brett taste to it, pretty tamed on the Brett.  Spicy, interesting not my favorite. Its okay.

Interesting brew with a flavor that isnt easy for me to decipher.  It reminded me of a pumpkin ale a little.  I wouldnt have known it has Bret yeast if the bottle didnt say so.  Slightly peppery and slightly tart.  Hints of lemon.  Relatively unique and somewhat mysterious.

.

Burnt orange color with a lacy white jead. Clean aroma with wheat and lemon and rich barley malt. Active carbonation. Smooth start with a bite on the end. Flavor is literally like a half hefe and an amber with some spice and lemon mixed in. It tastes sort of like a beer cocktail. The finish is malty and lingers with lemon zest.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 Poured hazy with a beautiful orange glow and a half finger head. I expected the aroma to be much more fruity, but I could only smell a faint yeast aroma. Had a slight tartness, but you could definitely taste the spices in the aftertaste. Overall it was a mediocre beer and I expected more from New Belgium.
Pours hazy orange with medium head.  Aroma is sweet fruits and caramel malts.  Taste is sweet, but the brett tries to sneak in unsuccessfully.  Odd bitter palate.

Tastes more like a citrus soda than a beer, unless you like something fruity do not bother tasting it.

Pours golden clearer with a light orange hue and decent sediment for a year and a half old. The aroma is light wild, infected yeast and some light sweet notes. The flavor is similar, light sweet notes, a bit of sour funk that goes down easy. More than a biere de garde, like a pleasant funky sour.
bomber pour. comes out a hazy orange with a nice white head. aroma of caramel, wheat and spice. good mouth feel, well carbonated. nice flavors of spice, lemon and yeast.

Bottle.  Pours hazy orangey amber with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma and flavor is slightly, pleasantly sour, some fruit (reminded me of a bock), maybe some coriander, lots of lemon (verbena?!).  Light, spritzy body.

(Draught at Meddlesome Moth) pale yellow pour with soapy white bubbles. Nose and taste have umami, sweaty socks, some light white pepper, Belgian yeast, and very faint brett. The palate linger isnt very good either. Disappointed. Had this from the bottle previously and liked its floral and brett influence better. Seemed lacking here.

Pours a copper color with an orange glow to it.  Aroma is of alcohol mostly with a hint of sweetness like caramel.  Taste is of strong alcohol like a lambic a little refreshing but not a simple tasting beer.  Overall, too strong alcohol taste for me, kind of tough to finish.

Pours burnt orange with a small white head. Smells kind of caramel or toffee like with a touch of spices thrown in for good measure. Tastes of caramalts and spices. Medium-bodied with a slick texture and some mouth-carbonation, New Belgium Lips of Faith Biere de Mars finishes like a sour ale but without the sourness, so... sweet.
Bottle. Slightly hazy golden with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, brett, bitter, oak, little citrus, little sour, little acid, dry and oranges.

Bottle 22fl.oz. @ HenrikSoegaard Sommerhus Tasting - Handrup Strand.Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, moderate yeasty, fruity, apricot, leather notes, light peppery. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, mandarin, apricot, acidic notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110626]
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with floaters. Aroma and taste are yeast, sour, fruit and bitter. Oily palate soft carbonation.

Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Moderate bitter very sour flavor. not even close to a Bier de Garde. This is a sour and not a pleasent one. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Bottle. Muddy orange colour with small creamy white mostly lasting head. Spicy aroma and flavor.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden/amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, yeast, fruits and hops.

A 22oz bomber from Picks Liquors poured into a trappist glass. Pours a dark orange with almost no head. Smells of yeasty bread and not much else. Taste is light bitter and light sweet. Palate is coriander and Christmas spice. Light bodied with a thin texture. Flat carbonation and a abrupt finish. Overall, its an ok beer. Ill drink and enjoy this time, but not pay $8.99  for it again.
Well done. Bready and doughy. Plenty of spice and yeast involved with this beer. Not overly sour or spicy though. Good stuff. Nice nose.
bottle, pours orange amber. not much head. Yeasty nose w/some malt, sweet taste, not as much body as Id expect. Ok, I guess.

This beer pours a medium orange color with a light orange head that doesnt last that long.

This smells very orangy, but not overpowering in any way. Has light notes of spice and lemon.

This beer tastes very nice, its smooth to drink but almost too drinkable, like a session beer but I dont think thats the intention. This taste is orangy but that goes quickly to some light hopes and a nice bitter end. Overall very good.

Pours a beautiful golden with a thin, white head that dissipates.  Aroma is sweet malt, spices, a little orange, and yeast.  Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, oats, spices, with a funky, yeasty finish.  A little booze lingers on the palate.  Very unique, and a good beer.

Bottle at the Funky 6. Pours rich gold with a moderate, off-white head. Spicy yeast and caramel malts on the nose. Fairly sweet with fruity notes and further spices and caramel, along with some mild funk. Medium bodied with average and smooth carbonation. Sweet, fruity finish, lightly tart and spicy. Very good stuff.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured as a clear golden blonde with a small fizzy head which dies out quickly. In the nose, there is a base of malts and alcohol with a suggestion of peach or apricot jelly begging to be noticed.  The flavor is sour and tart with the peach becoming more apparent but there is also a strange flavor of melted ice and canned peach juice. Nowhere near a Kerns apricot juice or other peach juices. Maybe more like a Snapples peach juice.  An interesting drink, but I would prefer the dark Kriek over this version of the Lips of Faith.

Deep amber with white head.  Some yeast sediment.  Coriander, ginger, allspice, sweet floral hops, lemon/citrus, and a tiny bit of funk.  Flavor is toasted malt, a hint of brief sweetness, and ends a touch like dry chardonnay.  Slight sour finish rounds out.  Light dryness clings to palate.

Tasted from a bomber purchased in Denver, Colorado.  Pours a hazy burnt orange body with a larger white head.  Yeast, sour citrus fruits and a great Belgian ale aroma.  Flavor is a nice lighter Belgian ale body thats somewhat spicy, somewhat yeasty.  Body is fairly malty with some sour citrus fruits in there.  Delicious beer.

The night was coming to an end and last call was in order. What did I order? None other then this bad boy. At this point of the night I had already tried 2 other Lips of Faith beers, both which were pretty good, so I  had high hopes that this would be just as good. Not as sour or tart as I was expecting, but still had a good aroma of spices and citrus. Nothing in the flavor really made my cheeks pucker all that much, but I definitely got some good sour notes to this one. It was a good way to bring a close to the night.

22oz Vegas bottle about 1 year old or so. Pours a clear orange-amber color with a medium, off-white bubbly head. Head reduces quickly with a little lacing. Aroma is definitely Belgian with some banana, cotton candy and a hint of tart sourness with some dusty oats as it warms. Fair amount of malt and oat in the flavor which was unexpected. The biere de garde notes appear in the finish for me. Fine.
22oz bottle pours a hazy, copper amber with a thin white head.  Nose is bretty, spicy, malty, sugary, yeasty.  Flavor is fruity, sweet, Belgian yeast, some coriander.  Medium bodied.

22 oz bottle. Hazy light copper with a spotty off white head that leaves some lacing. Musty aroma of cheese and dirty socks with some pepper, lemon and wheat bread. The flavor is earthy, musty yeast, tart lemon and some lightly sweet malt. Medium body with average carbonation and a spicy finish. My first foray into the Bière de Garde style, interesting blend of funk and spiciness. Will have to seek out more examples.

Draft. A dark golden beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with an odd malt note combined with caramel, and yeast. Maybe it is the oats that makes it a bit odd for me.

Bottle at the Where the Wild Beers Are event graciously hosted by Mission Dolores.  Pours a just hazy dirty amber gold with a thin white head.  Sweet malt and a light bit of musk.  Spicy malt, sweetness.  Malt and toast on the finish.  OK overall.

Bottle. Very fragrant nose of toast, apricot, quince, and mandarin. Pours a hazy gold-orange-brown with a solid head. Surprisingly bitter, with a smooth savory edge and a touch of herbal resin at the end. The spices are there, but they dont overwhelm and are more the backup singers than the lead. Quite good.

She poured clear yellow which was a bit of surprising; I expected at least a tinge of orange or amber hues. Atop her yellow-gold depths was a delicate white head which in no way hindered her nose from capturing my attentions. Spicy, yeasty, slightly funked, slightly sourish, nectarines, biscuits, and topped off by a subtle earthiness. She may be lighter on the eyes than most Biere de Garde, but so far everything is stacking up properly. My first quaff is sweet up front and dominated by a playful yeast character. Hops take the back stage, though inbetween her nectarines, peach skins, apricots, and apple skins, they share a brief moment in the tasting spotlight. Spice lingers long in her finish, filling my breath with cumin and ginger. An underlying dryness of fresh sawdust and I immediately come back for more. Nectarines are the dominant fruit, offering an almost nectarinecello quality with a thick, warm, slightly boozy presence. Warm fuzzies are officially established. As I laugh merrily with the other lucky recipients of the Lips of Faith, I am reminded of just how lucky in life I am.


Lips of Faith isnt easy to find (in Florida), and so I say thank you to the geek behind OBP for sharing his bottle.

Slightly hazy amber with off-white head that laces well. Smells wheaty and yeasty with spices. Tastes of spices, ginger, maybe some pumpkin pie spices, yeast, wheat and citrus. Medium bodied. Very nice.
Good stuff.  Pours an orange-yellow color with a medium white bubbly head.  Aroma and taste both have a little funkiness and sour, with some lemon
Its a beer. Tastes good when I drink it. Has spices and malty flavors. I like beer.
Very vegetal aroma with some sweetness.   Pours hazy gold.  Cereal grainey flavor with a dry vegetal taste, some straw.  Not enough there.

It pours a light & hazy amber with thin white head and some lace. It has a single string of bubbles trickling-up from the bottom-middle of the glass. An aroma of sweet and bready malts, light hops, orange and citrus, peach and apricot, and mild spices. The mouthfeel is smooth, silky, and rich. Flavors of thick and bready malts, light hops, citrus, light apricot, and mild spices.
Pours a nice amber brown, smells of spices such as cinnamon and ginger and tastes of them as well. Not incredibly complex as far as flavor goes.

This pours out a light copper, almost golden colour. Smells primarily of cherries, but I also get a bit of licorice and basement funk. The taste of this beer hits the tongue with cherries and overripe peaches, however there is not much else I can detect. Finishes a bit like rice lager to create a complex and interesting taste profile
Surprised at the low rating on this. Smells nicely-some nice brettyness. Pretty clear. Peppercorn. Orange. Some rather dirty socks, also some fresh laundry. A bit of alcohol.

Pours golden with a white head that holds for a minute or two. smells of malt and some fruityness. runs well over the tongue with a good medium carbonation. good malty and fruity taste with a bready/fruity finish. very good beer next time i am going to let it sit in my cellar a bit longer.

Pours a sparkling copper-orange with a thin and rapidly departing head. The aroma is an inviting combination of crisp apple and a dry champagne sweetness. The flavor is bright and clean, with notes of sweet yeast rolls and a mild fruitiness that is enjoyable albeit difficult to identify (pears, unripened mangoes?). The flavor is a tad bit funky, but not sour or off-putting in any way. Flavorful, smooth, and quite pleasant to drink.
Yellow orange in color.. Aroma is spices and citrusy.... Flavor is malts, spices and citrus... Havent had many beers like it, quite delicious...

West USA trip 2010. Bottled. The aroma has yeast, some spice, citrus. Bit hazy, copper-golden coloured beer with a white, medium head. The taste is lightly sour/tart, yeasty/earthy and citric. Quite good and well balanced.

Thanks to blazer06 for this one.  Pours clear orange with a white head.  Nose is slight citrus, pepper, herbs, and definite brett.  Flavor is similar with citrus, herbs, pepper, light brett, and malt.  Interesting take on this style with a light brett that does not dominate, but compliments.
Light golden body. Some sour funkiness to the nose. The carbonation and texture coupling was a little offputting. Decent-ish.

22 oz. bottle from Randalls.  Pours a semi-cloudy orange-gold color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of farmhouse funk, orange peel, grains, spices normally associated with a fall beer such as nutmeg, pepper, and apples.  Flavor of farmhouse funk, orange and lemon citrus, apples, spices, and cereal.  Light-medium bodied, with a spicy, funky mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Pretty cool beer.

Slightly hazy copper coloured body with an orange glow and a very thin white head. Aroma of strong spices, coriander seed, curacao, nutmeg, allspice, malt, alcohol and a touch of hay and grass. Medium-bodied; Assertive maltiness and alcohol up front with a lot of barnyardie type flavours and some strong spices as well. Aftertaste is fairly dry, with a good malt backbone and perhaps a bit too much alcohol. Overall, a good example of the style with a lot of complexity in the flavours and a nice drying finish. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased by good friend haddon90 - Thanks Phil!!! From BevMo in Walnut Creek, California on 17-July-2010, sampled at home on the Eastern Shore of Virginia on 24-July-2010.
Dark orange color with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt and some fruit notes. Flavor is bready caramel malt and banana and other tropical fruits.
Bottle. Pours a golden color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish spicy yeasty aroma. Fruity malty and slightly yeasty flavor with hints of citrus. Has a sweetish malty spicy yeasty finish.
Pours copper with a small head.  Nice aroma of spice and some light fruit.  Flavor is belgian yeast, spice, citrus, wheat, grass.  Tasty.

Pours golden with a white head that holds for a minute or two.  smells of malt and some fruityness.  runs well over the tongue with a good medium carbonation.  good malty and fruity taste with a bready/fruity finish.  very good beer next time i am going to let it sit in my cellar a bit longer.

Somewhat clear amber color with a decent whitish head. Light spices in the aroma. Maybe some malt. Hint of oats and wheat too. Some wheat and orange notes...as well as an interesting mix of spice. Very interesting brew. But they mixed it very well to where its very pleasing to drink.

Pours a clear medium golden color with a medium white head.  The beer has a lot of small bubbles moving quickly up through the beer.  This beer has the aroma of spice and citrus and is a little sour smelling.  This beer tastes like sweet (but not too sweet) spices and has a bit of a malty aftertaste.  This beer is easy drinking and crisp but is a little fuzzy in the mouth.  Overall, this is a nice crisp beer with good body and flavor.

Clear golden orange with a small white head that doesnt last long. The aroma is bretty, with some sweet grainy malt and citrus zest. The flavor is a nice mix of bret and sweet malt. Some lemon comes through on the finish.

Served from bottle into Duvel tulip.  Pours a copper color with a one finger off-white head that subsides to minimal upon sitting.  There was no apparent lacing throughout.  The aroma was comprised of fruit, malt, and subtle alcohol.  The flavor was of fruit, bread, and very subtle alcohol.  It had a light feel on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this is an excellent brew.  It is very drinkable and not overpowering.  Definitely suggest this for anyone who has yet to try it or want to try this style.

Bomber into a New Belgium glass.  Pours a hazy orange with no real head to speak of.  Some citrus fruit and hay on the nose.  Tastes of apricot, lemon, and crisp hops.  Finishes with a little of that Brett sourness.

Bottle, shared with Dave. Pours a hazy light amber with a towering white bubbly head that retains beautifully. Aroma is sweet and slightly toasty, with soft sweet spices and light fruit. sweet flavours of hay, honey, light toast, mace, ginger, and candied apricots. Really tasty and interesting.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 22oz bottle to pint. Pour is a striking hazed  orange.  Aroma is of strong spice, grass and cherry. Taste is sweet, bubblegum, banana, sweet grass. Medium sticky body with average carbonation. Finish is sweet and abrupt. Very nice sessionable beer.

Pours a slightly-hazed orange-amber into the glass.  The nose is of distinct pie spices and some light barnyard notes.  Flavors are of lemony malt (I know, describing a citrus hop directly with its malty counterpart sounds weird, but its so....).  This segues perfectly into a nice dry pie-spice finish.  The lemon hangs around a bit, turning somewhat yeasty in the aftereffects.  The mouthfeel is medium-light and goes down well enough, despite all the contrasts at work.  A decent brew, and one that Id definitely have again.  Probably my new favorite from New Belgium Brewing.
pours a hazy orange with small head.  tastes of lemon, bannanas, and light spice.  refreshing and sublte with no over the top flavors but very enjoyable.

Draught at a beer festival. Pale marmalade/apricot-hued with parchment foam. Lemony and zesty funk aromatics. Amazing brett character- leathery, peppery, goaty- marries perfectly with biscuity background malt. Pit fruits and maybe even a cherry note. Teasing hop and spice flavors. Paradoxically crisp and oily mouthfeel at the same time. Masterful... not only the finest NB offering, but the best brettanomyces-brewed beer Ive had, period. I enjoyed several pints and they were all wonderful
Aroma is exotic spices and brett.  Not as much in the flavor though, lightly sweet and spiced.  Pretty nice, but not great.

In short: A nice barnyard almost funky golden ale.  Highly sessionable pleasant surprise..
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed fresh the day of purchase
The look: Almost clear light golden body topped by a small persistent white head
In long: Nose is pleasantly farmhouse/wild and osier basket.  Taste of vanilla cookies, funky barnyard, leather, horse saddle, citrus fruits.  I could drink pints and pints of this stuff.  Ridiculously underrated.   I bought this beer to drink at the hotel when I had to spend a night in Atlanta because my connection flight to Rome was delayed.  This was because of the infamous 2010 Eyjafjallajökull volcano eruption.  Better known as simply the 2010 Iceland volcano eruption.  For obvious reason.

Pours orange with white head, aroma is full of spice with some banana, and wheat character.  Taste up front is some fruity wheat, moving into a bit of spice and finishing a bit funky and dry.  Not bad.

On draft at Small Bar (San Diego, CA): Pours out a light yellowish golden color and topped with a two-finger white head. Nose is of murky barnyard horseblanket, orange, lemon/lime, perished tangerine, caramel malts, toffee, hay, leaves, pepper, and lighter brett notes on the backing. Flavors of toffee, barnyard funk, hay, hardly some light grassy bitters (just barely), stuffy banana and orange, perished sour lemon/lime, mild spices, and yeast. Mouthfeel is soft and somewhat creamy. Drinkability: Wishy-washy, bland. Pairing: Shoestring fries served with lemongrass aioli. Rebuy: No. #435 on 30042010, DG.

From the bottle, pours a clear yellow amber with a nice white foamy head, nice lacing.  Aroma is sour, much like a farmhouse ale.  Taste is very mild but far from bland.  While cold, its just a little sour.  As it warms, still sour, but flavors of cinnamon and other spices.  Quite drinkable when cold, still good when warm.

Cloudy orange, little head. Nose is bright and citric, slightly sour and lemony. Crisp bite on the tonge w/ vigorous carbonation. Medium bodied. Some nutty, earthy malt sweetness. Slightly oily mouthfeel. Not as funky as I hoped/expected but still a reasonably complex brew.

Had from bottle, cant quite remember where I got it - probably Hi Time Wine.  Pours a nice amber/brown color with a good head.  Smells of spices, hops and bread/yeast.  Taste similar to aroma, complex, very well rounded.  A bit funky, spicy and malty.  Finishes a bit sweet and fruity.  Lovely.

(bottle - 22 oz) Hazy amber in color with a fizzy white head that disappears rather quickly. Slightly dry and funky aroma with nice earthy notes and some very light spice. Flavor has a subtle sour and funky tang at the start but then moves to a slightly sweet and almost Christmas-y spiced middle. Finishes sweet and slightly spicy with a very faint hint of that funk. Pretty good.

Fairly light in color almost a light tan.  Aroma is a bit of funk and spice.  Much more funk on the flavor profile than in the aroma.  Slightly to the wet horse blanket side of things.  Balanced with a bit of spice.  Interesting combo.  Definitely notice the brett.  My only real issue is how much I loved the old biere de mars.  I know it is a totally different beer but still I miss that.

Bottle thanks to JCB!Bottle pours transparent tea color, thin white head thats gone in 3.645 seconds. Sweet nose of cinnamon, butterscotch, and bubblegum. Flavor has a bit more fruit and ginger. Some significant grassy bitterness and lightly tart cherry in a finish that lingers on a very creamy body, only the slightest carbonation but enough to lift the very soft palate. Really soft beer, but the more BdG I drink, the more it befits the lightly sweet, spiced style. This is such and so works nicely.

A fairly clear golden hue, with a white bubbly head that settled down to a light layer and small ring of lacing. The nose was a hint of yeast and bread, spice, and some banana peanuts. The flavor was light malt, woody, grassy and somewhat dry. Okay and sessionable

Nice lemony, yeasty aroma. Pleasantly dry and sour on the palate. Many light fruit flavors-apricot, citrus, peach-playing faithfully on my lips. The coriander shows more in the afterrtaste. This is a very tasty and well made beer, but Id like it to be a little bigger and bolder. How about a Double Mars?

Bomber purchased at brewery.  Pours a hazy golden orange color.  Decent head with lots of lacing.  Aroma is light with notes of funk and citrus.  Flavor is slightly funky, with notes of coriander, flowers and mild hops.  Dry finish and a little fizzy for my taste.  Refreshing, but nothing fancy.

Growler from the Libation Station in Johnson City, TN. Pours a hazy rust color with a medium offwhite head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of musty tartness, citrus, caramel, lavender. Taste is oats, caramel, bread, spice, citrus, plum, floral and earthy notes, and a faintly tart finish. Medium bodied and fairly strongly carbonated. Texture is smooth and almost creamy. Good beer.

Slightly hazy orange-tan color, with a creamy off-white head.  I get cinnamon, nutmeg, and the slight herbal touch of verbena in the aroma.  Reminiscent of over spiced/herbed American Saisons, Bierre De Garde, and a touch of spiced Winter Ale all rolled into one.  And it works.  Well.  Gentle on the palate, leaves you with a spiced sweet aftertaste, quite complex.  Brett is pleasantly mellow and really completes the whole picture.  This is a world class beer, delicate and exquisite.

Aroma is very distict barnyard horseblanket,something that is celery like,and some light spicing,light malt tastes  along with the horseblanket funk,orangy sweetness ,light all around,but satisfying. Thanks Kingpin

Orange amber color with a suprizingly clear liquid and a white head. Medium sweetness with little to no bitterness.  No sourness and a very light hint of salt. Medium body and a thin/oily texture.  Not much carbination.  Long pleasing finish.  A beer of choice for me

This poured a murky orange color with a large white head. The aroma was quite yeasty with some brown sugar, yams, and citrus showing up. The flavor was rather sour but also had a sugary side to it as well. The flavor also contained some candied yams and citrus. Overall I really enjoyed this beer.

Picked this up the other day at Star. Not too shabby! Pours a bright orange with a fluffy white head. Got a bit of sour smell, but it was more citrus lemon sour then something poor. Taste was noticeable spicey and unique. Flavours of lemon, leaves and pepper. Mouthfeel was very spritzy. Very lively and creamy near the finish. Cool beer. id pick it up again!

On Tap at Barleys Brewhaus. Pours hazy orangeish brown with off-white head. Aromas of funk, citrus, yeast, and malt. Flavors of brett, caramel, malt, and some citrus. Mouthfeel has soft but had good carbonation. Had light tartness. Pretty solid beer overall.

Aroma: caramel, basement aromas, citrus.
Appearance: amber, clear, minimal head.
Taste: medium sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour.
Palette: medium body, creamy, lively, long finish.
Overall: Not bad, would drink again

A: A sort of orange/copper color, about one finger of white foam that recedes fairily quickly.

S: Spice, yeast, not really any sort of funk that I was expecting from the Brett.

T: Rather bland, especially for what I was expecting. Mild spice and yeast flavors, otherwise bready.

M: Medium body, with mild carbonation.

D: Drinkable?: yes. Great (or even good)?: no.
